description:
Blastomyces dermatitidis ER-3 is a dimorphic fungal species that can cause a serious systemic mycosis known as blastomycosis. It is a member of the genus Blastomyces, which belongs to the phylum Ascomycota.

The ER-3 strain of B. dermatitidis is a clinical isolate that has been widely studied in the laboratory. In its yeast-like form, which is the pathogenic phase, the fungus appears as round, thick-walled cells that reproduce by budding. In the environmental, saprophytic phase, B. dermatitidis ER-3 grows as a mold with septate hyphae and produces infectious spores called conidia.

Infection with B. dermatitidis ER-3 typically occurs through the inhalation of the conidia, which can then transform into the yeast-like form and disseminate throughout the body, causing a range of clinical manifestations, including pneumonia, skin lesions, and disseminated disease. The fungus can be difficult to diagnose, and its treatment often requires a combination of antifungal medications.

Research on the ER-3 strain has contributed to a better understanding of the biology, epidemiology, and pathogenesis of blastomycosis, with the ultimate goal of improving the diagnosis, management, and prevention of this potentially life-threatening fungal infection.
